title: Design Principles: Crafting Effective Experiences
description: A progressive exploration of fundamental design principles applicable across various disciplines, from visual and interaction design to systems and experiences.

paragraphs.summary: An overview of design as a purposeful process of problem-solving and creation, aiming to improve functionality, aesthetics, and user experience.
A principle asserting that the shape or configuration of an object or design should primarily relate to its intended function or purpose.
A design philosophy and process in which the needs, wants, and limitations of end-users are given extensive attention at each stage.
The perceived and actual properties of an object that suggest how it should be used; clues about its function.
Explicit indicators or clues (labels, icons, sounds) that communicate possible actions or the current state of a system when affordances are not clear.
Information sent back to the user about what action has been done, what result has been accomplished, or the current state of the system.
The relationship between controls and their effects in the world. Good mapping ensures controls have an intuitive and immediate effect.
Designing similar operations and elements for similar tasks, ensuring predictability and learnability across a system or product family.
The principle that relevant parts of a system should be visible and convey the right message about what is possible and how to operate it.
Physical, logical, semantic, or cultural limitations that guide actions and make a design easier to use by reducing the possibility of error.
The arrangement and presentation of design elements to imply relative importance and guide the viewer's attention through the composition.
The distribution of the visual weight of objects, colors, texture, and space. Can be symmetrical, asymmetrical, or radial.
The principle that items related to each other should be grouped close together, creating visual units and reducing clutter.
Placing elements so their edges or centers line up along common rows or columns, creating a sense of order and connection.
Reusing the same or similar elements throughout a design to create consistency, unity, and strengthen the overall theme.
The juxtaposition of different elements (e.g., color, size, shape, texture) to create visual interest and emphasize importance.
The empty space between and around elements of a design, crucial for readability, clarity, and reducing cognitive load.
The principle of aiming for clarity and ease of understanding by eliminating unnecessary complexity in design.
The problem-solving principle that entities should not be multiplied beyond necessity; the simplest explanation or solution is usually the correct one.
Describes the time it takes for a person to make a decision as a result of the possible choices: increasing the number of choices will increase the decision time logarithmically.

A predictive model of human movement primarily used in human-computer interaction, stating that the time required to rapidly move to a target area is a function of the ratio between the distance to the target and the width of the target.
Principles of visual perception that describe how humans tend to organize visual elements into unified wholes (e.g., proximity, similarity, closure, continuity).
A user's internal representation of how a system or object works. Designs are more intuitive when they match users' mental models.
The designer's representation of a system, which should be effectively communicated to the user through the interface.
The gap between a user's intention to act and the actions required by the system to achieve that goal.
The gap between the system's state as presented to the user and the user's understanding of whether their intended goal has been met.
How easily users can accomplish basic tasks the first time they encounter the design and how quickly they can learn to use it proficiently.
Once users have learned the design, how quickly they can perform tasks.
When users return to the design after a period of not using it, how easily they can reestablish proficiency.
Designing systems to minimize the likelihood of user errors or to make errors less catastrophic.
Designing systems that allow users to easily recover from errors they do make.
How pleasant or subjectively satisfying it is to use the design.
Designing products, devices, services, or environments for people with disabilities, ensuring equal access and opportunity.
A design methodology that considers the full range of human diversity with respect to ability, language, culture, gender, age, and other forms of human difference.
Designing a system as a set of distinct, independent components (modules) that can be developed, modified, replaced, or interchanged separately.
The capability of a system, network, or process to handle a growing amount of work, or its potential to be enlarged to accommodate that growth.
The ability of a design to accommodate a wide range of individual preferences, abilities, and usage contexts.
The ability of a system to cope with errors during execution or erroneous input, and to continue functioning despite them.
A phenomenon where users perceive more aesthetically pleasing designs as more usable, regardless of their actual usability.
A design methodology based on a cyclic process of prototyping, testing, analyzing, and refining a product or process.
An interaction design technique that defers advanced or rarely used features to a secondary screen, making applications easier to learn and less error-prone.
The process of orienting and navigating in physical or virtual space, involving perception, cognition, and spatial problem-solving.
The extent to which a product is attractive, enjoyable, and evokes positive emotions, beyond its mere functionality.
A biomimetic approach to the design of products and systems that models human industry on nature's processes, where materials are viewed as nutrients circulating in healthy, safe metabolisms.
An approach to innovation that seeks sustainable solutions to human challenges by emulating nature's time-tested patterns and strategies.
A human-centered, iterative approach to problem-solving and innovation that integrates empathy, creativity, and rationality.
Using narrative structures and techniques to create engaging, memorable, and emotionally resonant user experiences.
Designing products and systems with conscious consideration for their moral implications, societal impact, and user well-being.
User interface design choices that trick users into doing things they didn't mean to, often for the benefit of the business.
A holistic approach to analysis that focuses on the way that a system's constituent parts interrelate and how systems work over time and within the context of larger systems.
A method of describing good design practices or patterns of useful organization within a field of expertise (originated by Christopher Alexander for architecture).
Consciously designing products and experiences to evoke specific emotional responses in users (e.g., joy, trust, excitement).
